name: Lviv
fun_fact: Fun fact: A Lviv native named Yuriy Kulchytsky opened the first coffeehouse in Vienna in 1683 after stealing Turkish coffee supplies during the siege. A century later, when Lviv joined the Austrian Empire, Viennese returned the favor by opening Lviv's first coffee shops. Today, Lviv has the world's only 'coffee mine' where you wear a helmet and 'extract' coffee beans like coal

hero_dishes.name: Ukrainian Borscht
hero_dishes.description: Ukraine's soul in a bowl - deep crimson beet soup with beef broth, cabbage, potatoes, and a generous dollop of sour cream. Served with pampushky (garlic bread rolls) and sometimes in a hollowed-out bread bowl
hero_dishes.origin_story: Every Ukrainian grandmother insists her borscht recipe is the only authentic one. Some add prune and lemon zest (Trapezna Idey's version), others swear by rosehip broth (36Po), and purists demand only beef and beets. The debate has raged for centuries. What's certain: good borscht takes 3+ hours and can't be rushed
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Trapezna Idey (18a Valova St - with prune and lemon, basement of old monastery), Zashkvarka (with brioche and bacon), Kryjivka (14 Rynok Square - need password to enter), Medivnia (with medovuha tasting)

hero_dishes.name: Varenyky (Ukrainian Dumplings)
hero_dishes.description: Pillowy boiled dumplings stuffed with potatoes and cheese, sauerkraut, mushrooms, cherries, or even pike and rabbit. Topped with caramelized onions, sour cream, or butter
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Eastern European cousin of pierogi, ravioli, and gyoza - but Ukrainians will fight you if you call them anything but varenyky. Traditionally made by hand on Sundays by entire families. Sweet cherry varenyky are summer dessert, savory ones are winter comfort food
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Zashkvarka (halva filling!), 36Po (potatoes/mushrooms, pike, or rabbit), Amadeus (7 Katedralna Square - fancy versions), Kumpel (6 Vynnychenka St - fried varenyky)

hero_dishes.name: Salo (Cured Pork Fat)
hero_dishes.description: Thick slices of cured pork fatback, often with garlic and paprika, eaten on dark rye bread or straight up with vodka. It's pure white fat that melts on your tongue
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ukraine's most misunderstood delicacy. Salo sustained Ukrainian peasants through brutal winters - pure fat is calorie-dense and keeps forever when cured. It's a symbol of Ukrainian resilience. Proper salo should be firm but yielding, never rubbery. Eating it with vodka is tradition, not optional
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Zashkvarka (served with borscht), Kryjivka (Ukrainian Insurgent Army theme), Baczewski Restaurant (8 Shevska St - with 45 infused vodkas)

hero_dishes.name: Galician Cuisine Fusion
hero_dishes.description: Lviv's unique blend of Polish, Ukrainian, Jewish, and Austrian influences - think Wiener schnitzel meets varenyky, Galician sausages with Ukrainian pickles
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lviv was part of 8 different states throughout history (Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, Austrian Empire, Poland, USSR, now Ukraine). Each left culinary fingerprints. Galician cuisine is the sum of these occupations - neither purely Ukrainian nor Polish nor Austrian, but something uniquely Lviv
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Baczewski Restaurant (Galician cuisine with modern twist), Kumpel (Wiener schnitzel and sausages with own brewery beer), Trapezna Idey (lesser-known Galician dishes)

signature_drinks.name: Lviv Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Thick, strong Turkish-style coffee made in a copper cezve (turka), often with spices like cardamom or cinnamon. Lviv has hundreds of unique coffee recipes
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Never rush. Sit in baroque cafes for hours, order coffee with a shot of infused vodka (yes, really). Visit the Coffee Mining Company where you 'extract' coffee beans wearing a miner's helmet. The annual Lviv Coffee Festival draws 100,000 people. Coffee culture here rivals Vienna

signature_drinks.name: Medovuha (Honey Liqueur) and Infused Vodkas
signature_drinks.description: Medovuha is ancient Slavic honey wine, smooth and sweet. Infused vodkas come in 45+ flavors at Baczewski - horseradish, chili, herbs, fruits
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Medovuha served at Medivnia with live music. Infused vodkas are for tasting flights - try 5-6 varieties with salo and pickles. Baczewski family founded their vodka distillery in 1782. Always serve ice-cold, always with food, never shots without toasts

food_culture_notes: Kryjivka restaurant requires a password to enter - it's a recreated Ukrainian Insurgent Army hideout, most visited restaurant in Europe pre-Covid/war
Lviv printed the first Ukrainian book, built Ukraine's first railroad, and invented the kerosene lamp
Leopold von Sacher-Masoch (yes, 'masochism') was born here - the city has a complicated relationship with this fact
Despite ongoing war, Lviv maintains calm atmosphere and continues welcoming visitors with coffee culture and resilient spirit

landmarks: Rynok Square (Market Square) with colorful Renaissance townhouses
atmosphere: coffee aroma wafting from every corner
live jazz from basements and courtyards
unique_modern: Coffee Mining Company (only place to 'mine' coffee beans)
City resilience during ongoing war in 2025
